text.headline: THOREAU'S MAP OF MOUNT MONADNOCK
text.text:
The sketch of Mt. Monadnock at left is one of Henry David Thoreau’s most interesting representations of the mountain in New Hampshire. It's really a combination sketch and survey map.

It appears in Thoreau's Journal immediately following a page on which he describes his observations about visitors to the summit. Scroll down to see this page (verso in the Journal) and the facing one (recto) containing Thoreau's map. Note that the map is inverted with respect to the text on the facing verso.

Thoreau's map is much more than a simple freehand rendering. Only a cartographer or skilled surveyor could produce work of this quality. Owing to the compass bearings Thoreau took from the summit on August 8 and a linear measurement methodology he developed, the map's scale is true and the angles of its bearing lines are precise.

Page from Thoreau's Journal preceding his map of Mt. Monadnock. Image courtesy of the Morgan Library.

Thoreau's map as it appears in his Journal, inverted with respect to the text preceding it. Image courtesy of the Morgan Library.

text.headline: TAKING MEASUREMENTS
text.text:
From his experience as a surveyor, Thoreau knew how to use a compass in the field, but his map of Mt. Monadnock also shows his creative system for measuring distance.
The basis of my map was the distance from the summit to the second camp, made by rudely casting a stone before. Pacing the distance of an easy cast, I found it about ten rods, and thirteen such stone’s throws, or one hundred and thirty rods, carried me to the camp. As I had the course, from the summit, and from the camp, of the principal points, I could tell the rest nearly enough. It was about fifty rods from the summit to the ravine and eighty more to the camp. (H. D. Thoreau, The Journal of Henry D. Thoreau, XIV:39)
With his Journal open to the still blank recto page, Thoreau made his starting point, marked "Peak" on the map, the location where he stood to take his bearings on August 8. Because of the mountain's footprint, he instinctively knew that the summit point should not be positioned in the center of the page. Beginning at a point just right of center, he entered the north-south lines, “faced” south, measured S40E, and drew the bearing line a distance of one hundred thirty rods to "2D Camp," with a scale of eighty rods to the inch. With the bearing line and position of that camp set on the paper, the other bearing lines, contours, trails, streams, and points of interest all fell into place.

text.headline: A MATTER OF PERSPECTIVE
text.text:
Thoreau drew his map from his own perspective at the summit, looking south. Consequently, his "S" for "South" appears at the top of the manuscript page (see detail below) rather than at the bottom as is customary in maps. (Recall that the map at left is rotated to put north at top.) The map that Thoreau included in his book Walden is similarly inverted to show the pond from the perspective of the house he built by the shore.


Detail of map as it appears in Thoreaus Journal, oriented with South at top.


Thoreau's map of Walden Pond, drawn from the perspective of his house (marked "House" at lower right). Note the arrow pointing downwards (northwards) labeled "True Meridian."

text.headline: FIRST CAMP
text.text:
Thoreau's marking "1st Camp" bears approximately S6E from the summit. An important feature not distinguishable on the printed map as it appears in the 1906 Torrey and Allen edition of Thoreau's collected writings, or in any other printed version, is the penciled word “Ravine” inside Thoreau's marking of a "Swamp." (See detail above, which shows the map in its north-at-top orientation for ease of reading.)

While no map or book cites this ravine as a notable feature, there is no question about its presence when reaching the summit via the eastern approaches. On both the Pumpelly Trail and the White Dot Trail, visitors make a steep and rocky descent at about 2,800 feet prior to the final steep ascent up the rocks to the summit. A close look at Thoreau’s map reveals a curved line to the right of the word “Peak.” This line is a mark of that ravine, and it begins where he wrote the word “Ravine.”

That designation is important because it establishes the location of Thoreau's first camp as being west of the stream that runs down the middle of the ravine and also south of the rocky cap—most likely just off the Paradise Valley Trail. Immediately beside “1st Camp,” Thoreau drew a circle with a dotted line to mark the rocky mesa near the camp. Just to the west of the circle is a very small triangle, possibly representing the shape of the spruce lean-to in which Thoreau and his companions slept. In a letter to H. G. O. Blake, his companion on the 1858 trip to Monadnock, he referred to this site as “that memorable stone 'chunk yard,' in which we made our camp.”

text.headline: NORTHEAST SPUR SUMMIT
text.text:
Today, the Pumpelly trail runs over the location Thoreau has marked “NE Spur Summit” in ink. Along that ridge, the first high point or summit is now referred to as Town Line Peak. At 2,920 feet, it is the high point of Pumpelly Trail situated at the Jaffrey-Dublin town line. This ridge has three “summits,” each lower than the one preceding it. Thoreau has marked the second in pencil as “2D summit.”

To the south of "NE Spur summit," Thoreau has indicated the presence of two swamps. By the largest of these he has written, in ink, “NE Swamp.” Today, that swamp is known as “Thoreau Bog.” A line, first dotted and then solid, runs from that swamp north towards the village of Dublin (not indicated on the map). The name of that stream is Mountain Brook. The smaller swamp is on the southern side of the ridge and is marked but not labeled. From that swamp a runs a line to the southeast representing Ark Brook.

text.headline: MEADS BROOK
text.text: Two other streams are also noted on the map. In the southeast quadrant, A solid inked line runs from the ravine and the swamps in a southeasterly direction. The name of that stream is Meads Brook, and it is most likely the stream for which Thoreau wrote that he wanted to observe its source on his next visit (see Journal, XIV:52). [The relevant Journal excerpt could be included here.]

text.headline: FASSETT BROOK
text.text: In the southwest quadrant, west of where Thoreau has marked “South Spur Brow" in ink (the location is now referred to as “Point Surprise”) a solid line runs north-south with a small bend at the top. That solid line represents Fassett Brook. It runs off the mountain south to the Troy Reservoir and thence to Perkins Pond.

text.headline: PASSING THROUGH THE PLATEAU
text.text: From "2D Camp," a dotted line runs to the northeast towards “NE Swamp” and “NE Spur Summit.” The line marks Thoreau's path  through the area he called “the plateau.” It crosses the high point of the eastern spur, which Thoreau did not name or identify other than to write that it was where he would walk each morning to view the sunrise.

text.headline: PATH TO THE SUMMIT
text.text:
Passing between the S45W and the S5W bearing lines (in the southwest corner of the map), Thoreau drew a dotted line in ink crossing Fassett Brook and continuing towards "1st Camp." The line marks what is now called the "Paradise Valley Trail." It passes "1st Camp" and continues through the “Ravine” and the “swamp,” winding its way to the summit. This is the trail Thoreau forged from the base of the mountain all the way to the “Peak.”
